title: 114_hr253
content: The Act titled "Incentivize Growth Now In Tomorrow's Entrepreneurs Act of 2015" introduces Small Business Start-Up Savings Accounts under Subchapter F of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This new part allows for the establishment of Small Business Start-Up Savings Accounts to encourage entrepreneurship. The "Incentivize Growth Now In Tomorrow's Entrepreneurs Act of 2015" introduces Small Business Start-Up Savings Accounts, which are exempt from taxation but subject to unrelated business income taxes. These accounts are trusts created for qualified start-up expenditures by designated beneficiaries, meeting specific requirements. No contributions accepted unless in cash, limited to $10,000 or compensation amount. Trustee must be a bank or meet requirements. No investment in life insurance contracts, no commingling of trust funds. The trust assets cannot be commingled with other property except in a common trust fund or common investment fund. Qualified start-up expenditures are defined as per section 195 and include the taxpayer's share of such expenditures in an entity where they hold stock or interest. However, this term does not apply if the business has more than 50 full-time employees in a taxable year. The tax treatment of distributions is outlined in section 72. Distributions for qualified start-up expenditures are not included in gross income if the expenses exceed the distributions. The tax code allows for exclusion of distributions related to qualified start-up expenditures from gross income, based on the ratio of expenses to total distributions. No deductions, credits, or exclusions are permitted for these expenditures if they are already excluded from income. Excess contributions can be returned before the tax return due date. Excess contributions to small business start-up savings accounts can be distributed before the tax return due date, accompanied by the net income attributable to the excess contribution. Excess contribution refers to any contribution exceeding the allowable amount for the taxable year. Rollover contribution allows for the transfer of funds from a small business start-up savings account to another account within 60 days. Transfer of an individual's interest in a small business start-up savings account to a spouse or former spouse under a divorce or separation instrument is not taxable. After the transfer, the account is treated as belonging to the spouse. If a surviving spouse becomes the designated beneficiary of a small business start-up savings account after the account beneficiary's death, the account will be treated as if the spouse were the account beneficiary. In other cases where someone else acquires the account beneficiary's interest due to death, the account will no longer be considered a small business start-up savings account. The fair market value of assets in a small business start-up savings account at the date of death is includible in the gross income of the beneficiary or their estate. Special rules apply in such cases. Special rules apply to the reduction of inclusion for predeath expenses and the deduction for estate taxes in cases involving small business start-up savings accounts. The section allows for certain individuals, excluding the decedent or their spouse, to receive amounts included in gross income. Community property laws are not considered in the application of this section. Custodial accounts can be treated as trusts under specific conditions. The section allows for certain individuals, excluding the decedent or their spouse, to receive amounts included in gross income. Custodial accounts can be treated as trusts under specific conditions, except for the fact that it is not a trust but constitutes a small business start-up account. The custodian of such account is treated as the trustee. There is also an adjustment for inflation in the dollar amount for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015. The trustee of a small business start-up savings account must report contributions, distributions, and other relevant matters to the Secretary and the account holder. Reports must be filed and furnished to individuals by January 31 of the following year. Regulations will be issued by the Secretary. The Secretary will issue regulations for reporting qualified start-up expenditures of an entity in which the taxpayer holds stock or interest. Additionally, a small business start-up savings account is added as a prohibited transaction under section 4975(e) of the Code. Code is amended to exempt individuals and contributors to small business start-up savings accounts from certain taxes. Failure to provide reports on these accounts is also addressed in the amendment. The amendment exempts individuals and contributors to small business start-up savings accounts from certain taxes. It also addresses failure to provide reports on these accounts. Excess contributions to small business start-up savings accounts are defined in the amendment. The amendment addresses excess contributions to small business start-up savings accounts and exempts individuals and contributors from certain taxes. It also includes provisions for distributions and contributions to these accounts. Effective Date: The amendments for small business start-up savings accounts apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2014.
